awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CDS&E-MSS: Exact Homological Algebra for Computational Topology
awd_abstract_narration:
A central problem in data-driven scientific inquiry is how to interpret structures in large data sets uncovered by modern tools. The field of topological data analysis provides a potential solution via the language of homology, which encodes features of interest as cycles. These, in principle, can be located and understood as generators, which reveal explicit structure in the original data. However, fundamental mathematical and computational challenges have restricted most topological analyses to the study of persistence diagrams, numerical summaries that omit generators and, thus, dramatically limit modeling power and explainability. This project draws on diverse ideas from the mathematical domains of algebraic topology, numerical linear algebra, category and order-lattice theory, computation, and combinatorics, and from the scientific and engineering domains of biological aggregations, brain, and medical imaging. It provides ample opportunities for training mathematical scientists for the mastery of these tools, and for developing new, exploratory methods in STEM teaching and learning.


The ExHACT project will provide the tools needed to realize the full modeling and explanatory capability of generating cycles by creating a unified theoretical and computational tool set for persistent homological algebra. Recent results in the fields of matroid theory and exact categories (from which the project draws its name) developed by one of the PIs provide the foundation for efficiently performing the necessary computations using well-understood matrix manipulations. The PIs will capitalize on this new opportunity by developing theoretical and computational tools for the study of persistent generators, induced homomorphisms of persistence modules, exact and spectral sequences, and relative persistent homology, among other methods. They will augment this computational core with data visualization capabilities to facilitate graphical exploration of homological data in an intuitive fashion for scientists without extensive mathematical background, and provide new tools for existing research groups that currently apply topological methods in materials science, neuroscience, biochemistry, and biological aggregations. ExHACT will also enable custom functionality and workflows to be built by more experienced users, providing a stable community platform for the development of new methodologies in topological data analysis. All software functionality will be extensively documented, including both technical specifications and detailed use cases, in order to make a full suite of computation and visualization capabilities accessible to a broad audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental issue faced by modern data science is how to detect meaningful structure in complex, high-dimensional data. Topological data analysis addresses this issue by computing a signature of shape, called persistent homology, for the data. Persistent homology provides a coarse measure of shape appropriate for noisy and poorly sampled data, that can then be interpreted in collaboration with domain scientists.

However, this interpretation step is primarily performed in an ad hoc fashion. Due to the computational and size complexity of topological methods, state of the art software packages for computing topological signatures do not store the mathematical information needed to connect persistent homology explicity to data, nor to perform more sophisticated mathematical analyses like searching for minimal geometric representations of shapes detected by persistent homology or direct comparison of the measures across data sets. 

The ExHACT project created a unified theoretical and computational tool set, called Open Applied Topology (OAT). Utilizing sparse and lazy computational methods, the OAT suite of tools provides a mathematically complete computational tool set for directly studying the topological structure in high dimensional data. Using these tools, project personnel have studied optimization methods that allow us to localize geometric structure in data sets. We have developed novel techniques for using observations of cross-similarity between systems to register geometric structures in different systems against one another. This provides a mathematically rigorous approach to comparing their topology, allowing us to extract robust, quantitative relationships between two unstructured datasets; thus, it plays a role similar to procrustes alignment and full correlation matrix analysis (FCMA) which have become fundamental tools for understanding cognition in humans and machines.

The project has produced a major software package which is being prepared for public release. In addition, the project has produced two peer-reviewed publications, with five further papers in development. The project personnel trained several graduate and undergraduate students in methods of applied and computational topology, and these students then contributed substantially to the project's work. Two postdoctoral researchers were trained in computational topology and applications to complex biological data. New collaborations were developed with researchers in basic neuroscience, human psychiatry, avian ecology, forest ecology, and the science of science. The work has been presented at a variety of domestic and international conferences. Project personnel also organized a workshop at the American Institute of Mathematics, where researchers considered open problems of relevance to the ExHACT project and broader computational topology community.

Looking forward, Pacific Northwest National Labs will be providing ongoing financial support for OAT, which serves the research goals of the lab as well as its government sponsors. This continued support will allow us to continue to extend the capabilities of the package, and to develop training materials and use cases that will facilitate its use in a range of contexts. Future development plans include zigzag persistence, which models a much broader range of relationships between complex data sets; interactive query and data visualization; and, scalable high-performance computing. We will continue to foster the nascent community surrounding the software, which has already borne fruit: collaborators at the Universities of Oxford and Alberg have written first versions of open-source software extensions, which will be used as templates for the 17 other collaborating institutions. Together, we will use the tools developed in this project as a foundation for new research communities in computational topology, including collaborative development of technical training and undergraduate educational modules.
